title: 115_s850
content: The "Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017" aims to establish consistent eligibility requirements for foreign medical schools to increase accountability and protect American students and taxpayer dollars. Congress finds that three for-profit schools in the Caribbean receive the majority of Federal funding under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 for students enrolled at foreign graduate medical schools, despite being exempt from meeting the same eligibility requirements as other foreign medical schools. The National Committee on Foreign Medical Education and Accreditation and the Department of Education recommend that all foreign graduate medical schools should meet consistent eligibility requirements. Foreign graduate medical schools should meet the same eligibility requirements for Federal funding under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The attrition rate at US medical schools is 3.4%, while for-profit Caribbean medical schools can reach 30%. In 2016, residency match rates for foreign trained graduates were 54% compared to 94% for US medical school graduates. Students at for-profit medical schools have lower success rates. Students at for-profit medical schools outside the US and Canada accumulate more student debt than those at US medical schools. The text chunk states that there is a repeal of grandfather provisions. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require that at least 60 percent of enrolled and graduating students in a foreign medical school are not U.S. residents. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require that at least 60 percent of enrolled and graduating students in a foreign medical school are not U.S. residents. Additionally, for students seeking loans under part D of title IV, at least 75 percent of individuals taking medical school examinations outside the United States or Canada must be students or graduates. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require that a passing score in medical school examinations administered by the Educational Commission for Foreign Medical Graduates is needed for students seeking loans under part D of title IV. The authority of a graduate medical school to qualify expires after a certain period. The Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017 requires a passing score in medical school exams by the Educational Commission for Foreign Medical Graduates for students to qualify for loans under part D of title IV. The authority of a graduate medical school to qualify expires after a certain period. SEC. 5. LOSS OF ELIGIBILITY. If a graduate medical school loses eligibility for loan programs under the Higher Education Act of 1965, enrolled students can still receive loans if they meet academic progress requirements. Students at a graduate medical school can continue to receive loans if they meet academic progress requirements, which include withdrawal, completion of the program, or the fourth June 30 after losing eligibility.
